sentences: Dawid Sofius Engela (30 October 1931 – 25 November 1967) was a South African broadcaster, composer and musicologist.
He was born in Florida, a suburb to the west of Johannesburg, Transvaal (now part of the province of Gauteng).
He was the only child of David Jakobus Engela (1895–1962) and Sophia Hendrina Fredrika Engela (1903–1991, née Buys).
He was the only child of David Jakobus Engela (1895–1962) and Sophia Hendrina Fredrika Engela (1903–1991, née Buys).
He took an early interest in African music and song and would attend Sunday afternoon church services in the African neighborhood to make closer acquaintance with the music of the people.
This knowledge evidently contributed in later years to his decision to set two poems by Roy Campbell including The Zulu Girl to music; these poems describe typical Zulu characters.
In 1947 he matriculated from Voortrekker High School, Boksburg, with a first-class pass and distinctions in Latin, Mathematics, Physical Science and Music.
He registered in 1948 for a BA degree at Potchefstroom University.
At this point Engela was aiming to enter the ministry, but soon realized that his future career lay in music.
He nevertheless decided first to complete the year's study at Potchefstroom.
In 1949 he registered for a three-year B. Mus. degree at the University of the Witwatersrand.
Engela's long association with the broadcast media began on 1 December 1948, when he took a part-time job as an apprentice record program compiler in the SABC record library.
In February 1950 he resigned from the SABC to pay more attention to his studies; nevertheless he handled the music column in the weekly SABC magazine, Radio, from June – August 1950.
In February 1950 he resigned from the SABC to pay more attention to his studies; nevertheless he handled the music column in the weekly SABC magazine, Radio, from June – August 1950.
At the end of 1951 he completed his B. Mus.
studies and immediately (in November) rejoined the SABC, this time as announcer/producer.
He held this post until May 1953.
In May 1952 he met the young singer Mimi Coertse.
They married on 25 July 1953.
They wished to further their music studies in Vienna from January 1954, but first would undertake a tour of Europe.

As a result they departed for London in September 1953 with individual two-year music bursaries of £25 per annum awarded by the Federasie van Afrikaanse Kultuurverenigings (FAK – Federation of Afrikaans Cultural Unions).
This would deal with 'Harmony in the music of the early seventeenth century, with particular reference to the works of Monteverdi, Schütz and Schein'.
Engela's application for a permanent post at the BBC was successful and he was appointed from 1 September 1956 for a contract period of three years.
Engela's application for a permanent post at the BBC was successful and he was appointed from 1 September 1956 for a contract period of three years.
Later it was extended and eventually he was in the service of the BBC for seven years, during which time he became a naturalised British citizen.
In September 1956 Engela registered as a student at the Royal College of Music.
In April 1958 he passed the ARCM Performance Diploma examination with distinction.
In the same year he also passed the written examination for the D. Phil. degree in music history.
His plan was to complete his doctoral thesis within eighteen months.
Its title was to be 'Periods of crisis in musical thought during the past millennium in Western civilisation and their relation to the present musical revolution'.
In 1958 he met the Scottish contralto, Ruth Morrison, whom he married in December of that year.
In 1958 he met the Scottish contralto, Ruth Morrison, whom he married in December of that year.
In 1958 he met the Scottish contralto, Ruth Morrison, whom he married in December of that year.
From this marriage two children were born, Charl (1960) and Jeannie (1961).
From this marriage two children were born, Charl (1960) and Jeannie (1961).
This marriage also failed, however, and was finally dissolved in January 1967.
In 1962 his father died.
The performance by the English Stage Society took place on Sunday, 27 November 1960, at the Royal Court Theatre.
The performance by the English Stage Society took place on Sunday, 27 November 1960, at the Royal Court Theatre.
At the end of August 1963 Engela left the BBC.
During September the family moved to Cape Town where he took up the post of Music Organiser for the SABC on 1 October 1963.
During September the family moved to Cape Town where he took up the post of Music Organiser for the SABC on 1 October 1963.
He held this post until February 1965 after which he began work as music manager of the Cape Performing Arts Board (CAPAB) in March 1965.
He held this post until February 1965 after which he began work as music manager of the Cape Performing Arts Board (CAPAB) in March 1965.
On 1 September 1967 he married for a third time, this time to a person without musical training – Ansie Fouché.
On Saturday 25 November 1967 the couple left Cape Town for a short visit with his mother in Boksburg, before leaving on a long-planned overseas visit.
